START.question: Do you think there is anything you are experiencing at this very moment, or is that uncertain?

options.label: I don’t think there is anything real to experience

Q2.question: Right now, does what you experience feel like one continuous, unified whole, or like many separate things?

Q2a.question: Is this because everything genuinely feels unified, or because you can’t distinguish parts yet?

options.label: I just can’t distinguish the parts yet

Q3.question: Do some things happen or appear again, or is everything always completely new?

options.label: Some things happen or appear again

Q4.question: When things seem to repeat, do any persist as the same individual, are they recurring instances of a kind, or is it impossible to tell?

Q5a.question: Do repeating things have a fact of the matter about their identity, or is the distinction confused or meaningless?

options.label: There is a fact but it’s inaccessible
The distinction itself is confused or meaningless

Q5b.question: Is your inability to tell due to perceptual limits, or because it’s impossible in principle?

Q6.question: Do things persist when not observed, or do they exist only while being noticed?

Q6a.question: Is your uncertainty due to conceptual confusion, or because the issue is genuinely difficult?

Q7.question: Are recurring patterns imposed by the mind or do they exist independently of us?

Q7a.question: Are these mental patterns arbitrary, or are they shaped or constrained by how experience works?

Q7b.question: If kinds exist independently, do they exist apart from instances, only in instances, or not at all?

options.label: Kinds don’t exist; only resemblance does

Q8.question: Do persisting things exist only because minds perceive them, independently of minds, or through an interaction of both?

options.label: Exist only because minds perceive them
Depend on both mind and reality

Q9.question: If things depend on minds, do they depend on your own mind, minds in general, or collective/social minds?

Q10.question: Do you perceive mind-independent things exactly as they are, or could perception misrepresent them?

options.label: Perceive them exactly as they are

Q11.question: Do mind-independent things appear as they truly are, or only as they appear through perception?

Q12.question: Do appearances give real access to things, is reality ultimately beyond reach, or is the question itself misguided?

options.label: Appearances give genuine access to reality
Reality exists beyond appearances but is unknowable
